R: @tgroh
R: @tgroh

Implementing the Distribution metric revealed a lot of problems with some of the internal mechanism in the first commit. Happy to squash those together prior to review if it makes things simpler -- just let me know.

How easy would it be to split this into two commits, one which uses `BatchTimerInternals` everywhere it's relevant (and does any relevant refactoring that moves it to `InMemoryTimerInternals`) and then a second that's just the rename.

Which rename?

In terms of offered features, `ReduceFnTester.TestTimerInternals` > `TriggerTester.TestTimerInternals` > `BatchTimerInternals`, so I created `InMemoryTimerInternals` which is almost equivalent to `ReduceFnTester.TestTimerInternals` (i.e. powerful enough for all 3 use contexts) and used it everywhere.

The old BatchTimerInternals can't be used anywhere except the one place where it was already used.

And ReduceFnTester is in the Testing package. Hrm. That's disappointing.

So, I'm going to propose a history that lasts for the duration of the PR:

Split `ReduceFnTester.TestTimerInternals` into the `ReduceFnTester` and the `TestTimerInternals`, move `TestTimerInternals` to `InMemoryTimerInternals`

Use `InMemoryTimerInternals` everywhere, delete unused code

After the PR, these can be squashed together; but should make reviewing the two steps simpler.
Good idea. Split into 3 commits.

I've started working on most of this at:
https://github.com/dkulp/incubator-beam/tree/gridfs-t2
Comments welcome.     Will work on this more tomorrow.
+1 for this feature
Such an useful idea, great. Question, is there already a sort of BIP or other document about the proposed Metrics API ?
Please, submit a PR for the review.
By the way, `getCurrent()` should return `NoSuchElementException` if `ObjectId` is null.

I don't see use of `SourceTestUtils` to test split and estimated size. You can take a look on what I did in ElasticsearchIO (https://github.com/jbonofre/incubator-beam/blob/BEAM-425-ELASTICSEARCHIO/sdks/java/io/elasticsearch/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/elasticsearch/ElasticsearchIOTest.java) as example.
I will provide a link to gist containing some improvements proposal.
It looks good. Thanks ! Need to take a deeper look.
+R: @swegner

`SourceTestUtils` doesn't invoke `splitIntoBundles` per se, but it provides `assertSourcesEqualReferenceSource`. You should call `splitIntoBundles` yourself with various parameters and verify the result using that function.

It also indeed doesn't test `getEstimatedSize` - that has to be simply unit-tested manually.
Thanks Thomas, merging with Jenkins green and personal travis green; travis for Apache seems baclogged again.

R: @tgroh
I'm sure you've seen this does not pass yet :)

I would think we would want to add compression at the root, aka, where we create the channel. https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/FileBasedSink.java#L494

Is there a reason not to make this an option on FileBasedSink itself?
Closed in 759b6cada9f1b724e32457b900a469f8a113542d

Yeah. I give up because the generated Avro code contains warnings (until they release https://github.com/apache/avro/pull/124 and we update avro plugin) and I couldn't find a way to suppress them, nor to tell javac to omit this warning for that file, nor even to make javac use different parameters to compile tests than to compile the main code.

I'd rather resume after Avro gets fixed.

By "option", do you mean just modify FileBasedSink to accept a CompressionType parameter at initialization time?  I think that would be the optimal solution wrt ease of use.

The reasons I did it this way were:
1. The idea to submit the solution upstream was somewhat of an afterthought.  Ie, this was originally going to be just in my company's code base.
2. I was unsure if this would just cloud (forgive the pun) the existing FileBasedSink API.

I'm more than willing to redesign this to be inline with the existing Apache Beam patterns.  Let me know and I'll see what I can come up with?
Jeff, yes that's exactly what I meant. Great!
R: @lukecwik @dhalperi

Reviewing.
By the way, the Travis CI has been stuck on Examples run.
Cool.  I just got Eclipse setup with \@AutoValue processing, etc.  Will get back to the task of incorporating this into FileBasedSink tonight or tomorrow.

@dhalperi I'm planning on putting the code that wraps the underlying `OutputStream`s in, eg, a `GZIPOutputStream`, into the `IOChannelFactory.create()` implementations (I see two concrete impls currently).  This way we don't end up with an OS wrapped by a Channel wrapped by a OS, etc.

The existing API seems to go back and forth between the two quite a few times, so maybe I'm being too cautious?

Merged @jkff improvements, added connection pool configuration.

What about preventing fusion in the `Read` `apply()` ?

Yeah, I think I'm being too cautious.  Plus, the changes for GCS would end up going much deeper that route.  I'll just simply wrap the channel in another OS/Channel pair, unless I hear an opinion to the contrary.
This is being preempted by https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1019 et al
Add random key generation, following by GroupByKey and then ungroup to prevent fusion.
R: @lukecwik
LGTM assuming you fix the empty executeBatch() thing. Thanks for bearing with me!
Updated: prevent to do `executeBatch()` if the batch is empty.

@iemejia : We have some thoughts on the general direction but no formal document prepared -- I'm working on writing one up that I'll share on the mailing list. In the meantime, I'm happy to answer any questions you may have on the mailing list!

@swegner: Updated to reflect your comments. Right now, the direct-runner only commits physical counters at the end since they're now cumulative. I'll look at a mechanism to manage tentative physical values as an addition.
LGTM. Thanks.

Mmh, it seems that Travis and Jenkins have an older pip version installed. 

Not quite sure how to solve this if not by upgrading pip and writing some regression tests - or simply stating in the README that pip 7.0.0+ is required, and then we could remove the check in the setup.py script.

@dhalperi 
Let me know if this looks good to you. The changes I made to the `TextIO` and `FileBasedSink` APIs provide an easy way to add GZIP and BZIP2 to any file-based output and are now inline with the existing fluent `TextIO.Write` API.

The travis-ci build directly on my fork passed fine, but the one on the PR failed due to what looks like a transient issue with `.travis/test_wordcount.sh` that happens quite often, across PRs.  Not sure what action, if any, the PR creator can take to trigger another travis-ci build in these cases.

I also included a fix to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-697 in this latest commit, FYI.

Thanks
